description: From Middle English drunken, ydronken, idrunken, from Old English druncen, ġedruncen (“drunk; drunken”), from Proto-Germanic *drunkanaz (“drunken”), past participle of Proto-Germanic *drinkaną (“to drink”), equivalent to drink +‎ -en. Cognate with West Frisian dronken (“drunk; drunken”), Dutch dronken (“drunk; drunken”), German betrunken (“drunk; drunken”), Swedish drucken (“drunk; drunken”).

adjectives.description: drunken (comparative more drunken, superlative most drunken)

entries.meaning: Drunk, in the state of intoxication after having drunk an alcoholic beverage.
examples: What shall we do with a drunken sailor?  […]  / Put him in the longboat and make him bail her / Early in the morning.

entries.meaning: Given to habitual excessive use of alcohol.
Characterized by or resulting from drunkenness.
examples: a drunken display of crude exuberance

entries.meaning: Applied to various spicy stir-fried dishes in Asian cuisine.
examples: drunken noodles; drunken duck; drunken fried rice

entries.meaning: (archaic, still occasionally in juxtaposition with eaten) past participle of drink

description: From Middle English dronknen, drunkenen, drunknen, from Old English druncnian (“to drown; get drunk”), from Proto-Germanic *drunkanōną (“to get drunk”), from Proto-Germanic *drunkanaz (“drunk; intoxicated”). Cognate with Norwegian drukne, drukna, Icelandic drukna.

verbs.description: drunken (third-person singular simple present drunkens, present participle drunkening, simple past and past participle drunkened)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make or become drunk or drunken; intoxicate
